comment.body: I'm not very good with bit-fiddling code.  Just wanted to check you're confident this is correct.  I recall that a [recent FrodoKEM commit](https://github.com/microsoft/PQCrypto-LWEKE/commit/669522db63850fa64d1a24a47e138e80a59349db#diff-40aa21688f1ac58ddf8ef5f0f4e472e6075411f5c4f75b9c1d512b7e03a2cbabR120) to this type of code got it wrong so it's worth double-checking.

pull_request.title: Remove Picnic's compatibility layer
pull_request.body:
We've had some problems with duplicate symbols being introduced by picnic's OS/libc compatibility layer, which needs:
* aligned_alloc
* aligned_free
* explicit_bzero
* timingsafe_bcmp

We already provide everything except for timingsafe_bcmp in our common code. This PR adds an implementation of "timingsafe_bcmp" (`OQS_MEM_secure_bcmp`) to our common code, and then removes Picnic's compatibility layer.

Resolves #1022

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.body:
The FrodoKEM code tries to work entirely with 16 bit integers, which makes it more complicated than it needs to be.

The trick is to cast to a larger width integer before doing the negation.

As the comment says, we have 0 <= r < 256, and unsigned int is guaranteed to be at least 16 bits. So we have
```
 (unsigned int) r = ... 0000 0000 xxxx xxxx
```
where by "..." I mean there might be more than 8 leading 0s.
There are two cases to consider, r=0 and r!=0.

If r=0 then
```
- (unsigned int) r = ... 0000 0000 0000 0000
```
Shifting right 8 places and extracting the low bit gives 0.

If 1 <= r < 255 then, -(unsigned int) r is between UINT_MAX-255 and UINT_MAX (inclusive).
So in binary it looks like:
```
- (unsigned int) r = ... 1111 1111 xxxx xxxx
```
Shifting right 8 places and extracting the low bit gives 1.
